ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was only one real live virtual lecture with the professor. After that just submitting things via email, and there will be final presentations live in a virtual manner.
independent lab
N/A
The was independent self-directed research, with the only virtual component being the final presentation
Given that this course was research for credit, there was no real "instruction"; we worked on our own and had regular meetings with our advisors.
Virtual meetings several times throughout the semester for different purposes
Almost entirely virtual. Able to stop into the lab a handful of times.
Independent study with proposal, midterm, final paper and presentation.
Virtual one-on-one weekly meetings.
This was an independent study/research course
This was a research course and my research was data science focused so it was all remote, with weekly checkins with my principal investigator.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Working on my research project, I learned time management skills, how to present to a collaboration, and how to carry out a computational data analysis project.
How to work with professors in conducting research
I worked on a project on nanoparticle synthesis using the properties of supercritical fluids.
I was able to hone my research and science communication skills through the midterm and final reports, as well as the final presentation
I learned a lot about the modern experimental physics process and the graduate physics experience, in addition to quantum atomic physics.
Research methods.
This course was great research experience. I was able to read papers and apply that knowledge to my own projects

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is required for physics majors. It is perfect how it is.
It's a pretty standard research for credit. I wish the professor was clearer about what he expected in the midterm report and final report.
The course is good. The reports due during the semester helped me stay on track.

My biggest frustration was the process of finding an advisor. There is no formal process for getting matched with an advisor and I probably emailed 20 professors before finding one willing to take me on. When I eventually found an advisor he was not in the field I had wanted to work on, and he was very clearly too busy to pay much attention to me as he already had multiple undergraduates and graduate students who he was advising. I wish there was a better/clearer process for matching students with advisors and projects.

I would have appreciated a little more direction on what was expected of each report, but also the flexibility of that allowed me to tailor my reports to that parts of my research that were most interesting/relevant, so that freedom also ended up being one of the strengths
Really hard to do a course like this during COVID. I dont blame the professors or anyone else, just poor circumstances.
N/A
I wish we had more presentation time. I feel like a midterm presentation would be great alongside a final presentation like we already have.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was lucky that my research was all computational, so it wasn't disrupted much by the pandemic. The final presentations were all through Zoom, which was discouraging because most people were video off, mic off. I felt like I was presenting to a blank wall and Charles Baltay.
Not really relevant here, the biggest change is that my research is virtual
Communication could have been slightly better but it was almost impossible to run this course during a pandemic.
N/A

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're a physics major and are doing research. Because it is required for your major. If you're not a physics major, probably not.
sure
Yes, research is a necessary skill to develop if you want to become a scientist.
It's honestly low workload and fun if you find a cool project to work on.
Required!
If you're not interested in doing physics research, there's no reason for you to take this course. If you are interested, however, it'll be an easy and informative credit.
Yes if they are majoring in physics or have interest in participating in research.
yes
Yes, every student conducting physics research should take this course.
Yes

This course is great, but I imagine it varies depending on who you choose as your faculty sponsor. Be sure to read up on the research going on in the department and find someone who you think you will work well with.
